CTR.Q: What type of chart is this?

VEC.Q: How many ridgelines are in this ridgeline chart?
VEC.A: There are {7} slices in this chart.

SRP.Q: What is the spatial relationship of the peak of Physical Education relative to the peak of Language Courses in terms of vertical (above/below) and horizontal (left/right) directions?
SRP.A: The peak of  Physical Education is to the {left} of the peak of Language Courses.

VPR.Q: What distribution pattern does the ridgeline representing Humanities show?
VPR.A: The ridgeline representing Humanities shows a {Single Peak Distribution}.

VPR.Q: At what value do  Humanities reach its peaks?

EVJ.Q: Which ridgeline has the highest peak
EVJ.A: The ridgeline representing {Social Sciences} has the highest peak.

EVJ.Q: Which label has the highest density at X =39.5?
EVJ.A: At X =39.5,the label with the highest density is {Physical Education}

NF.Q: Which countries in the ridgeline chart have ridgeline peaks exceed 65? Please list the countries and corresponding peak values.
NF.A: {Language Courses}'s peak at {82},{Social Sciences}'s peak at {69},{STEM Subjects}'s peak at {81}

NF.Q: Which countries in the ridgeline chart have ridgeline peaks below 39? Please list the countries and corresponding peak values.
NF.A: {Arts}'s peak at {12},{Vocational Training}'s peak at {6},{Humanities}'s peak at {11},{Physical Education}'s peak at {28}

NC.Q: Which one has a larger X value at the peak of its ridgeline: Vocational Training or Arts?
NC.A: {Arts} has a larger X value at the peak of its ridgeline.

NC.Q: Which one has a larger X value at the peak of its ridgeline: Social Sciences or Language Courses?
NC.A: {Language Courses} has a larger X value at the peak of its ridgeline.

MSR.Q: How many ridges have their peak located to the right of the average X value across all ridges?
MSR.A: There are {3} ridges whose peaks are located to the right of the average X value.

MSR.Q: What is the label of the ridge with the largest span along the mountain height?
MSR.A: The ridge with the largest span in the mountain height is {Social Sciences}
